Chickanic says Round, actually round and not an indented pattern like that one or with a tab on one side, is best because those shapes and tabs and curvy stars and points take away from the overall core diameter, making it weaker and easier to break, where round is the diameter you get. That is, a .090 round is .090, where the shapes and points reduce the core diameter of .090 to something much less for the trimmer string to fit in the same feed hole. It's a sales gimmick to make you think you're getting something when it actually makes you purchase more trimmer line. She also says to buy the diameter that the manufacturer states on the box and in the manual. Getting larger creates issues, like clogging from hanging while exiting through the hole because the hole is too tight now for proper feed. Also, those points and patterns cause the trimmer line to stick and bind together on the spool as it feeds out, due to the centrifugal force tension of the pulling. I know I've had to tear it apart from the spool to get it to feed again and wondered why. I don't know about you, but I'm going with Round of the manufacturer's stated size from now on.

Alternative Method. I would weed eat a separate area of a fairly uniform yard with each separate line. I would then have consumers and experts judge the quality of the cut for each area. They would look at the grass from a stand up view and from a kneeling view and maybe even a magnifying glass view. You could even make it double-blind if you took the effort. In this case, tensioning the grass and using slow motion seem quite silly as a way to judge performance in the field. Go to the field. You will find thousands of example cuts instead of three.

On the positive side, using slow motion video is usually entertaining. I would say slow motion is the winner rather than any of the weed eater lines.

I somehow missed this, was probably sick with crawdad at the time. The "star" and "shuriken" both produce high speed vortecii in their channels, line's ability to cut is based on its ability to remain at a high enough speed to cut so you want line that smacks the two parts of the cut grass out of the way.

The knipper dents on the Titanium are to keep it from fraying at the ends and producing a high amount of blunt drag that blows the grass down. The reason it screams is those little dents produce micro sonic vorteci. It really isn't all that more likely to snap at those marks.

One of the main impairments to trimming is the knife and shield on the trimmers, the tip vortex and the suction created under the shield and around the knife actually use up torque from the motor/engine.

In the end it doesn't really matter what line you use as long as the line is appropriate to the grass you're cutting... Buy a Stihl 120v AC trimmer tho - its even worth dragging a couple hundred feet of power cord out. Mine's run every other week for seven years and I've not had to top off it's gas tank even once. (they cost a little more and need a cord but the savings is immense)

Robert's line that you used was also sitting in the back of his truck and subjected to the elements.  Heat, cold, sun, etc.  Which can alter the line's properties.  Which is probably why it was so stiff.  You can counteract that by soaking the line in a bucket of water overnight, which will rejuvenate it and make it flexible again.  In fact, in order to get a better baseline for the different lines, they probably all should have been soaked first, since you don't know how long each line had been sitting in the store waiting to be purchased.

like you were hinting at in your observation of weight different lines can be more beneficial to different situations. the square line stood out to me because one of the important jobs of the line isn't just to cut the grass, but it also has to discharge the grass away from the cutting path allowing you to get the next blade and so on. the design of the square line is so that it has a good edge to cut denser grasses while also having the wide flat edge to grab the grass and pull it out of the way for the next strike. round line is the cheapest way to achieve this effect since its not sharp and the flexibility of the grass means that it wraps itself around the line as it breaks allowing it to be transported elsewhere. but this process isn't terribly efficient so while its fine for common consumer for around the house. watch professional yard workers and how they run a trimmer. they don't slow down for anything moving as quickly and evenly as possible. so the square style line is ideal since it has good mass for denser grasses and weeds meaning they don't have to slow down during their walks along the road or driveway. and the ejecting strength of the line means it wont clog up in dense patches also allowing them to move more quickly in their task.

Have been mowing part time as a side job for 16 years. Here is a weedeater line durability improvement hack. Soak your line in water. Over time, line "dries out" and becomes more brittle. Thru the years weedeater line graduated to larger and larger diameters and eventually different shapes. Line size varies from .065, .080, .095, .105, and even larger. My experience started with smaller diameter line that was simply round in profile. There are trade offs to diameter. Smaller line slices grass much cleaner and with less resistance and like your neighbor said, allows for higher rpm. The trade off is that it wears down quicker. Larger diameter line seems to rip the grass/weeds down, has greater resistance (more tiring to use on big jobs) but is much tougher and lasts longer.

I used to use .105 because it was so tough, but after using .095 I realized it was still pretty tough, it cut much easier, and yes, I settled on the star shaped designed years ago. Another negative side affect of larger line is that it can pick up hard debris, (gravel, pebbles, small sticks) and sling it into your legs, ground level basement windows, sliding glass doors, or knock holes in your vinyl siding.

..some shapes cut faster/cleaner initially, but I have found over the years, the overall quality of the line is more important than the shape..weld resistance, breakage resistance, toughness..as to the shape, after you use it a few seconds, the dirt, gravel, sand, foreign objects it comes into contact with wears it all down to a more or less round shape anyway, regardless of it's shape when new..if I had to guess, I would say the square probably retains it's edges longest..but there again, it all depends on the quality of the material from which it is made..BTW, I am a 30+ year 2-cycle mechanic, specializing in chainsaws, trimmers, etc...I have also cut grass commercially in the past, also...what might be interesting, is try this experiment with different shape lines..AFTER they have been used trimming grass around the edges of a parking lot, etc. for a few minutes...

My wife and I weed whack about five acres of dry weeds 12" to 60" high every year to mitigate wildfire risk in the California foothills. Our land has rocks here and there of all sizes and shapes well hidden in the weeds. The large rocks are more visible and don't cause a problem but the smaller ones wear out the line fast. After trying various brands over the years we now only use the Husqvarna Titanium Force line since it holds up better when hitting the rocks. All the different lines we tried seemed to cut the weeds about the same so it was a matter of how long they lasted. We use the old fashioned heads where you wind two lines individually within the head because when we hit a larger rock near the spool it cuts it off at the spool and it's faster to open the spool and thread it through the openings.

Overall great video! Ive been working in the landscape business over 5 years. Now there really isn’t “the best line”. It all depends on what your doing. There is pros and cons with every string shape. Another thing to consider is the thickness of the line, for every shape and brand there is different thickness sizes. If your edging sidewalks, or weed eating somewhere with a lot of rocks, or metal or debris, then you would want a thick round trimmer line. This shape is especially made for not breaking as easy. If your weed eating thick grass or brush with no rocks in the way then I would use the diamond shape. Which looks like a twisted string. An example is the echo black diamond. Also known as “sharp square shape. This line is meant for thick grass and weeds. It is not meant for edging, nor weed eating around rocks, fences or debris, because this type of line breaks easy. In my business I only use Husqvarna titanium force. Which is a thick round line. I use this because this line does not break easy, it is durable, and can cut through thick brush. This line is not meant for thick brush, but because we have high power commercial trimmers it knocks down weeds like nothing.

I'm a golf course superintendent. One of the most important things I consider on a daily basis is cut quality, i.e. how cleanly the grass is cut. Think about it like this: grass is a living thing, like us. If we get a cut, the cleaner it is the easier and quicker it heals. The less chance we have for infection. Likewise with grass. It is susceptible to fungal, viral, and bacterial pathogens like anything else that is alive. So we strive to do as little damage to our plants as possible so they can be as naturally healthy as possible. In weedeaters, cut quality is irrelevant. I think you proved that. All of the string types result in significant tearing well beyond what we would consider "acceptable" on the golf course for our finer turf. So the real answer is one of economy. The better test would be to see which string shape is the most resilient against unnatural obstacles (stuff that isn't grass). You're weedeating because these are areas with obstacles that can't be reached by a larger mower. Which string will give you the most bang for your buck is the most important question.

I have one issue with the experiment. While you're trying to test the cross section of the various lines, in most of the footage the grass is not cut entirely through by the side of the line, but rather nicked, meaning that only the END of the line hit it - sometimes a couple times - before the grass was fully severed. This suggests to me that the comparatively sharp cut end of the line had more to do with the findings that the shape of its cross section.

I'm not entirely sure how to test this... ensuring the grass is hit with the side of the line rather than the end, and whether or not it even matters. If the end indeed does nearly all the work, it would seem that the cross section geometry would have almost nothing to do with the effectiveness of the line.

Perhaps try the same line cut multiple ways... a very sharp clean cut across the section, a cut diagonal to the section, a rounded over (sanded or melted smooth) end geometry, and a ragged or torn geometry. I suspect the last, ragged torn, would be the most indicative of normal use since the line is continually being beaten, stretched, and torn during a weed/grass eating/whacking session.

Seems to me the 'cutting' edge is basically defined by the sharpest point, not necessarily what looks 'blade' like (an acute angle edge, how ever an obtuse angle blade can still work as a blade). How the grass is cut or broken on that scale bears remarkable similarities with working hard ground. Being a plant operator i'm intimately familiar with how 'blades' operate on a large scale and how seemingly dull edged blades can effectively 'cut' better than sharp ones in certain applications, or how a seeming fragile or bulky blade can cut/break far better than a sharp pointy one. Working with machines over 20t i see quite remarkable similarities with 'cutting' or 'breaking' through ground. I use so many inverted commas because the terms cutting and breaking are so very relative dependant on scale, and this relationship is amplified to me by the similarities I mention. Which brings me to my point that the 'best line' doesn't really exist as it's determined by what you want from it. The star line gives the best cut as it strikes with so many cutting edges it will always hit the blade well and give a nice finish, however the many point will dull quuckly creating weak points and reducing longevity. The cored lines won't give as good a finish, but will have far greater durability for professional applications, but for someone like Robert the sharp sharp square would be ideal as he has to work across such a likely wide variety of scenarios (potentially working around hard/abrasive/undulating surfaces), and so a line that never straightens out will give an uneven cut and consequently help increase the work rate and efficiency of an adept user as they don'tneed to work to precisely over large areas. There are other benefits of course to more applications than i've mentioned, but for the best cut, my vote is for the star profile line, and i'll be buying my next reel in this shape to test it out.

Now you need to go find a large patch of long grass and watch the results of cutting bulk grass, which I call splatter, spatter, debris and line breakage.

Splatter is the finely shredded grass that builds up on everything and ends up forming a layer of green/black stuff that you then have to scrape off.

Spatter is the larger fragments which fly around and get stuck on surfaces like goggles and painted walls.

Debris is simply the large chunks of grass that are light enough to get flung into your shoes, gloves, mouth. This is the stuff you sweep up afterwards.

Line breakage is how much line you have to keep winding out because just trimming the grass is wearing your line down.

Then of course you have your current metrics of how clean the cut is (does the grass look like it's been mowed, or is it no longer identifiable as grass?) and how noisy the line is.

Dear Destin, and everyone who's reading this. Love your test but.... (this is gonna be a lengthy rant, sorry about that)

Firstly, you mentioned less noise from the non-circrular cross-sections. This, as I assume you referred to, has to do with a process called vortex shedding. At least that's what my bodies that study fluids at the high speed imaging laboratory told me. It's quite a cool phenomenon.

Anyway I wanted to go on about something else, fracture as that is my main interest. I wanted to point out various, not yet mentioned issues regarding the test. I assume that you agree that this high speed fracture process is of a dynamic nature and that many parameters play a role. Clearly the cross-sectional shape is only one of them, in the video Robert already mentioned the linear density. Some of these effects can have quite the impact on the test. Here two dynamics related examples.

1) I'm worried about the weight that was added to the grass, which will increase the inertia of the grass, hence it does not move much when it is hit by the grass eater. I do believe that this is not realistic and in many cases the grass might flex away instead of being 'cut' or 'raptured'. This could reduce the cutting capabilities of the line. And I would hypothesize that this effect could differ greatly between the cross-sections.

2) Rotational speed will affect the cutting performance and is affected by different factors. Imagine that the line is very light and that you're cutting something tough, as a result cutting it will slow down the line greatly, which might reduce the cutting performance, but this would only be noticeable if you were to cut many blades of grass simultaneously. Similarly lines with more drag are thus also likely to rotate slower. I assume that a lower rotational speed will result in a less stretched line and thus only cut a smaller area at the same time. Which will also influence your mowing speed.

I also wanted to point out some causes of the difference between the 'sharp-sharp square' line and the others like the star shape. Maybe the sharp-sharp line is meant for more professional use. Maybe the line does not become flat in your machine because it does not rotate as fast as Robert's machine. Faster rotation could flatten out the disk better and alleviate the issue of cutting at two different spots. You can use your camera to check this. Besides the test did not consider the durability of the line. I imagine that this is important for someone like Robert. The tougher like is likely more durable, as a result it could be more cost-effective. After all, you want to eat grass, not have the grass eat your grass eater line ;-)

It was a cool video to watch, and I learned a ton. Especially cool was to see the difference in fracture of the grass blades, the cleaner cuts do not only cut faster but would also require less energy. And less energy in the fracture of the grass, means more energy remains in the line to cut other grass blades. 'Delaminating' the grass blades is highly inefficient as all the cracks will absorb energy, which will likely not only result in slower cutting speeds but also strain your line and likely reduce the lifetime of the line.

From what I could see, the cleaner cuts result from higher surface noise across the string. An asymmetric spiral star pattern, in my estimate, would cut best. My personal theory is that it has the same to do with saw blades. They have square shaped grooves often because cutting wood is less efficient with sharp knife like blades due to the surface friction of wood. Also, the grooves help disperse cut material away from the next blade impact, otherwise you're just pushing cut debris into the area you need to cut, grinding it up more and losing efficiency. That little "plug" you see fly off of the square blade is exactly what you think. The cut debris gets trapped into those grooves and effectively creates a sphere. However the angular star shape has grooves that are almost larger on the inside, creating more effective cutting surfaces without debris getting in the way.

The next step I'd try is stress testing them. Find out how much they can cut before breaking. I can't imagine the star shape is very durable but the plastic nature of the wire makes me think the cutting difference is negligible.

I was expecting the star line to give the most consistent track and cut, based on the performance of dimpled golfballs vs smooth. I was very happy to see the slowmo footage bore that out! Given you don't want the cuttings to form a rotting slab covering and killing your grass, I like an accurate cut so the remains are easy to pick up and bag, rather than a messy cut that purée's everything into a vegan's idea of a smoothie.
If you're not going to pick up the cuttings, I suppose a stiff heavy line would be most economical, particularly if you don't entirely know what other biomatter or debris might be lurking in the grass. Exception, of course, being any terrain that could cleanly break (and thus launch) a significant chunk of line, such as sharp rocks or fencing. This is also why I dislike cored lines, as they have a tendency to break rather than fray, the latter of which produces a change in operating sound you can respond to, instead of a plastic flechette looking for something to skewer.

Awesome vid. Thanks, Destin! You spoke about the wraps on a car antenna to make it quieter. This may be so but the functional purpose is to slow down the electrons in the antenna. Electrons travel at the speed of light in an antenna. They bounce off the end and come back. The time it takes for them to travel that distance determines the frequency and corresponding wavelength. The wavelength of your car's radio is 3m, which needs a 1.5m antenna, but your antenna is far shorter than that. If you wrap wire around the antenna it slows the electrons down which extends the observed frequency. The more wraps you use the shorter the antenna can be! Pretty sweet.

You should take in to consideration other things too.
For example the star shaped line seems to travel in the very accurate rotation while the others are traveling in parabolic path cutting the same target in ~2 different positions.
Another thing to consider, how much it effects fuel consumption, because it should be harder for the engine to spin the line that is traveling in parabolic trajectory, also that could limit the power behind the cut.
Also heavier, beefier line is harder for the engine to spin, it may not seem much but it does feel when you face a grown grass area.
Another and probably the most important thing is how much line you use up when working. And the shape and obviously plastic quality is the answer here. The sharp edge plastic goes to waste a lot faster compared to the round shaped one. Also when it meets the fence it really wraps around it. The round shape slides around the hard objects and when it hits the hard object it bounces off of it. The sharp edge ones, they don`t bounce off they just wrap around the object until they break. Sometimes they can wrap up so much that your line gets pull out too much out of head so you need to stop the "weed eater" and wrap the line in to the head again...
Usually when I am on the field I notice that I tend to use around ~30% more square or triangle shaped line compared to the round one.
I get trying to make a controlled experiment but tension in a blade of grass with adding weight vs free standing grass just doesn't seem like it would be real world comparisons.

Also, the variable of how long each roll of string has been stored dry can be skewing your results. Store them all submerged in water for a week then try your experiment again. I would venture to say that they all act very differently after being able to soak up some moisture and when in actual use. I have an FS 560 that I use a string head on sometimes. I have tried a plethora of different types and sizes of string and have so far settled on Oregon gatorline .115” I did recently figure out that I have a gearbox issue which generates an unusually high amount of heat in the spool of the string head. The heat causes brittleness due to losing moisture(hyp) and and welding towards the inside of the spool. In trying to figure this out someone told me about the water for string storage, their reasoning was that most weed eater string is similar to monofilament fishing line which likes to remain wet. All the different brands and shapes of strings acted way better after being stored in water. Once I get the gearbox issue sorted I will be back at trying many different strings. All in heavy, dense, tall grass and weeds around farm equipment and fences.
Soak/store your weed eater string in water.

WRONG!! I owned and operated a commercial landscape company with up to 10 crews of 4-6 people  each. Your test has a flaw. NO BODY cuts one blade of grass, but you. The most important things to a landscaper are the amount of line consumed for even amounts of work, fatigue, and quality of the cut. When cutting lawn grass, round line is consumed less for 2 different reasons. It carries more momentum through thick grass by staying completely extending and reduced drag. The line has to stay flexible too so that it can bend instead of break. There are multiple diameters for running on the different  strengths of line trimmers. We ran ...095 round on 26cc trimmers when cutting municipal grass (weeds, grass, crab grass) but if a worker had to trim for more than an hour at a time he would need to switch to twist line(second best)for reduced vibration to limit hand and arm fatigue. Our guys could grab a line trimmer and hit a powerline easement and trim 4hrs out and 4 hours back. When dealing with a manicured lawn and a smaller powered line trimmer its better to stay with the round and reduce the diameter but stay with a flexible line. It keeps high speeds with clean cuts. The smaller line is like cutting with a shaper knife and the line trimmer stays in its power range. The titanium line you tried is a premium line with great results but very pricey, generic spools of round can be bought online and Shindaiwa makes the best twist line. We went through 5lb spools every week per crew and we got nearly double the time from round as we did any of the other shapes. They have there place cutting vegetation and saplings but a blade is better for that.

Did you consider how the motor of the weedwacker has to continuously accelerate the line of the trimmer and also how the aerodynamic efficiency of the line could improve the rate at which it regains in speed (after a deceleration from an impact) due to the decreased air resistance? Also when dealing with two solids colliding at high speeds the objects tend to behave more like liquids than solids, a follow up to the first study could be seeing how the line passes through a liquid (like water). The star line is only binding to the grass in small surface cross sections whereas the other lines were binding to the grass in larger surface cross sections. You were likely also thinking about a clean cut slightly incorrectly, Conventionally a clean cut is perceived as a cut where no material is lost and the two sides left behind after the cut are parallel. In the case of a weed eater a clean cut is one in which all the material in front of the path of the line is ejected, leaving behind a gap equal to the 'diameter' of the line. It's similar to how you need to take into account the thickness of the blade when making precise cuts with a circular saw.

Where do I start? All these tests are irrelevant because the line shapes are all the same after 5 feet of trimming. They all degrade into a frazzled, tapered round or oval shape. The 3 important things in weedeater line are toughness (slower tip wear), heat resistance, (less prone to melting and breaking inside the spool), and straight tracking. (flies in a straight line, easier to trim a neat, straight line). Now,,, line cross section shape can affect the latter 2 characteristics! Love your videos!

The star line acts like a multi dladed razor. The first ridge to impact stiffens the blade of grass, causing it to become rigid. Before that impact has time to rip the grass, the next ridge impacts slightly above and below the first, keeping the blade taught, while the first rips through. That process repeates again with the next ridge, and while each of the ridges cut, the shock is focused in that finite rigid area of the grass blade. Its almost like a psi ratio, i suppose.

You dont cut individual blades of grass, usually when its grown it gets densely packed, or has hardened roots outside the soil.

Sharp edged shapes gives you a rough finish, but can work faster, especially over denser vegetation.
Round shapes should be used for well established/fancy grass, it allows for the grass to be a uniform height texture, the perfect cut should be shadowless, you use the shadows to find imperfections.
You cant get that with a sharp shape.

I have to say, I think that the cut on a grass blade is really not the most important thing.  First of all, grass is pretty much going to be cut by anything, the important attribute of line is not the cut, it's the durability! This test was looking at the wrong kind of performance on some levels.  Resistance to wear is an important factor when you're trimming a whole property not just three blades.  Resistance to obstacles is also important, how much damage it will do to them and how much damage it takes. Second of all of all, I'm not sure the idea that a clean cut is superior is a foregone conclusion: I don't know plant biology but I know human biology and a clean cut (razor blade, a paper cut) bleeds much longer and more severely than a ragged cut (from a less sharp edge, a kitchen knife or torn metal).  Grass may suffer less trauma from a more ragged cut if it causes less moisture loss.

I cut lawns as part of my living as well - in London, Ontario, Canada - and I use a hexagonal trimmer line. It has always seemed to make a nice cut, and stands up well as well. PS, I often trade neat cuts against the wear resulting from brushing up against rock, masonry or concrete. I've got a theory on this interaction, but it requires some outlandish thinking. Instead of think of it as the Wacker striking through the blade, thinking of the blade snapping as it hits the Wacker string as an angle, the same as light when it hits a prism. But instead of like the light slowing and passing through the glass, splitting into its "parts", it is reflected back on the axis that it is hitting, the Wacker line. This is then where the tearing occurs, as the blade in contact with the Wacker line is now immediately stopped, the rest of the blade twist or bends around the Wacker line axis, and when the force axis, the force of the moving Wacker line, exceeds the amount of energy/force/tension/heat the material we're measuring the break on's structures tensile strength can handle, the first "crack" or break forms as the bonds are broken.

Here's where scientific test methodology has to be rigorously examined. Weedeaters are not meant to cut a single blade of grass, under tension.

I think it would be interesting for lawn companies and end users to fund research into not only best lines, but R&D of better lines...since line companies and end users have completely different goals.

I want a line that is heavy enough to blast through tough clumps of weeds, light enough to allow high velocities, not brittle, and wears down by slow abrasion rather than snapping off big chunks when twigs and rocks are encountered in tall weeds. Maybe I want too much, but I think there is quite a bit of room for improvement.

SO, as I always say... Don't do projects or tasks in the forward direction... always go backwards... Meaning figure out your end goal, then work your way backwards to the start and that tell you the best way to accomplish it.  So lawn care, and your "weed eater" test doesn't have any single end result.  What I mean by this... is what is it you want to accomplish.  So if you want healthy longer living grass, I'd assume a clean cut would help the grass stay green and live longer before browning or drying out.  But that's isn't exactly your best outcome for all end uses.  If it's just your house lawn... sure.  Makes sense.  Now if let's say this grass field is used for Soccer/football, or some other friction/less friction based end result... then maybe a frayed end of grass is better.  You'd have to do tests for that.  So First determine which line type cuts cleanest and which cuts with the most fraying.  Then do a round of test with say a weight on a stick on a hinge, at a given angular drop, and with a variety of balls, or other sports equipment, and see which cut grass type has more or has less friction.  Then do the test in a practice environment with players and real world scenarios and see if they like or need more friction or less friction on the ball or whatever, to have better game results.  So it would be a multi level testing but that would ultimately be the best use of your initial testing information.  Not to mention, I am sure the final results would be very helpful for professional sports teams of all kinds.  As that kind of possible advantage could make the difference, either in a team on team outcome, or in some "world record speed" type of scenario.  And it might end up leading to mixed results.  Like how golf courses have the length and type of grass different in different zones of the course, what if a soccer field was say cut with the lower friction resulting line on the bulk of the field, but with the higher friction inducing line to cut the grass in the goalie zone... or vice versa... depending on what the player tests shows they prefer.  Right?

Grass is pretty much impossible to achieve a clean cut on without a metallic blade with a honed edge. I recommend the experiment be enhanced exponentially to include different vegetation types. In most of the US, grass isn't a big issue. It's weeds. Then there is Florida. In southern Florida there is a popular type of grass called St. Augustine. It has a cousin named Floritam. They look like a thick shaggy carpet. They are actually vines. They are officially listed as a grass, but have more in common with vines. They eat electric weedeaters and lawnmowers under 5hp for breakfast. That stuff is thick. It grows fast too. In summer you have 7-10 days to cut it or you will have to whack it down with a weedeater first and baby step your lawnmower over the rest while it chokes. Unless you have a mower with 20+Horsepower. Test has merit to see which produces the least damaging cut which is important for grass health.
However, I hate to say it but hanging the weight on the grass is completely different from cutting grass. The weight obscures the ability of the line to "bite" into the free standing grass without sliding as the grass blade is bending out of the way.
A line which "bites" will cut the grass with minimal "bending over" resulting in a more accurate cut height. Now keep in mind that while a blade of grass is easy to bend, the string velocity is high and the higher it is, the more effect the grass blade's inertia comes in to play.
If velocity is quasi-static, the grass bends out of the way and nothing happens. If the velocity is extremely high, the inertia will keep the blade from bending at all and the bite of the string has no effect. Of course you could look at the cut: is it a nice slice like with scissors or a ragged rip. (NOTE: the test of good hedge trimmers is a nice slice and no rips.)
I believe if the line does not bite, the weed eater will perform poorly in high, dense, "needle" leaf grass (is that fescue?) I believe you were testing on a rye grass with a nice broad, thing leaf.

There's an extra factor that you haven't considered here. I use Oregon Starline and have noticed that it doesn't retain its shape and then break - in use the 'points' wear down until you are left with a thin cross-section at the very end of the line before it eventually breaks, so it is really acting as a combination of thin roundline and thicker starline. Here you are just focusing on the 'virgin' shape of the line and the real test is to see how it cuts as it wears down too - this would add complications to your experiments though.
Also, Oregon Starline has five points and the one you have here has seven. I would expect that too many points makes the line start to act more like it is a round line, ie the spaces are as important as the points

The grass simply can't handle that many points of impact and separation at such a high velocity. FYI, the spiral antenna thing is, as I understand it, to break up the frequencies of shedding vortexes so they don't resonate together. As with many dynamic systems, natural system frequencies are to be avoided. Basically the car drives down the road, and at certain speeds, the antenna will experience shedding vortexes that match the first natural mode frequency of the antenna (or some multiple thereof) and the antenna ends whips left to right as the car drives forward. Without the spiral wrap, the frequencies along a length of antenna of similar cross section can happen synchronously and then act on the antenna body as a uniform coherent load. This can cause fatigue and destroy antennas. It's actually pretty cool to watch a plain round antenna whip sideways relative to the vehicle motion for the first time (after you realize why it's doing it)... although I'm a nerd so maybe it's not that cool...
If you want to "visualize" shedding vortexes as they roll off a round rod in the wind, look at a flag on a pole. The flag waving motion is literally the vortexes rolling off the flagpole and moving the flag at that frequency. The frequency of shedding vortexes correlates to fluid (air) density, velocity, and the beam cross section. Some cars even use sensors to measure the frequency of shedding vortex within the air intake manifold to calculate mass airflow into the engine (for fuel mix ratio mapping). Shedding vortexes are also a big component in Lab-on-a-Chip micro-fluidic devices. Neat stuff.
Anyways, the spiral wrap just breaks up the coherency of the frequencies along the antenna beam so they can't act in unison and whip the antenna around. An alternative method to the spiral wrap is to have an antenna of varying cross sectional thickness from base to tip... which is the primary wind-bucking mechanism used by those old electronic telescoping retracting antennas from the 90s (fat at the base and skinny at the tip).

My own opinion, the Star shape cuts cleaner because each contact point regardless of its rotation is a uniform length when it touches with its flat edges. Occasionally it’ll cut using the vertices, and considering there are more of them, it’s also a higher chance you’ll make contact with one of those corners. You’re trading off a sharper edge for more edges, and consistency?

Also considering you’ve sacrificed how tight the edges can be and thickened the wire to create more contact points, it’ll have a harder time cutting thick grass more consistency due to the thickness

Star, all the way.  Been using it for over 20 years since first trying it out.  Cut acres and acres with it. So, one develops very careful techniques around wire fences and rocks. Besides all the flaws in the test that he mentioned there's another big flaw to the test and that is that the grass is held, and with tension which could dramatically changes how string would work. I said this b/c if you ever used dull scissor or something that's not held in tension (like flaccid piece of string) the scissors don't cut. But if you take that some thing, like the flaccid flaccid string and pull it so there's tension suddenly the scissors cut right through it. Grass isn't held in tension when your outside cutting it.

These tests also don't really tell you which string is better quality for the price either. Even though the thinnest line cut the best the test doesn't tell you how long the line itself will last or how often the line will need to be replaced. So although this was interesting to watch and a great video, I would have to say that we have really learned nothing other than what a weed wacker if called in different areas of the world.

I tried copper wire in my weedeater once...
It's too heavy, so it really taxes the tiny motor - and also the copper stretches (ductile) under the centrifugal force, and as soon as it hits the cutter/guard, it sends shockwaves down the wire and it breaks at its weakest point. That sends little whips of hot metal flying through the air toward your shins!

NOT RECOMMENDED! :)

I use 3mm nylon coated steel cable for most of my heavy weeds, anything tougher I use a 6 or 8 tooth blade. I have worked professionally with strimmers and brushcutters for decades, most of the fancy shapes just cost more, what really matters is how tough and wear resistant it is.
I pay about $15.00 for 45 metres of the steel cable from china and use a solid aluminium head that clamps four pieces at a time, that will easily cut an acre of tough weeds.

I just bought one of those push along string trimmers and was quite literally standing in Lowes last week at that display thinking "I really wish there was some sort of scientific analysis of which line was best".

When I started watching I said the winner will be the star shape. Why? Like a golf ball's dimples, the grooves cause less air turbulence allowing it to spin on a level plane, plus the surface area hitting the grass is consistent but with enough edges to split the fibres instead of pushing and delaminating.

The helical shape of the antennae is to reduce prevent it from resonating in the wind. This is because as the speed of antennae increases, the eddies behind the antennae grow larger and begin to oscillate the antennae back and forth. The helical pattern is to prevent the formation of these eddies.

This video was very well done, interesting, and informative, but not always instructive in real-world terms.

Whenever someone claims to have discovered "the magic string," I ask for several feet of it to try out.There are different approaches that work better for differing cutting circumstances. If I want to test capability against tough weeds, I use yucca leaves, knotweed, garlic mustard, various docks, and thick, matted grasses. These will test string, machine, and user. I test at high RPM's, because when I do real-world cutting, I approach tough weeds with the string already moving at near max speed. I will also approach at an appropriate linear speed and angle to allow cutting to occur instead of wrap-arounds, bogging, and string-breaking. I use a little slower RPM when edging adjacent to sidewalks and pavements.

It is very difficult to replicate real-world use with lab-type testing. (E.g., high-RPM, high-torque trimmers use string of various characteristics in ways that differ from lower-RPM, lower-Torque trimmers.) String that weighs less per linear unit might not feed well once it wears down to a length at which heavier string feeds smoothly. Experienced users know these things, and employ techniques that are not very lab-like to "automatically" compensate. This means that their experience might not be as predicted by certain lab-like tests.

Given that a particular string cuts acceptably, its durability can be assessed by doing the same job on two or more occasions, and comparing how many "bumps" of centrifugal-feeding heads are needed to complete the job (some strings require twice as many "bumps" as others, ergo, they are presumptively less durable).

When I put a load on my trailer and strap it down, the straps will tend to flutter and hum in the wind on the strap portions that don't touch the load.  When I throw a few twists in the exposed parts of the straps (strap not touching the load) there is no flutter in the straps. Personally, I think this provides enough info to fuel interesting theories. But I don't think it provides nearly enough to make a decision. The two big stand-out issues to me are that grass blades aren't taut, and aren't encountered one blade at a time. And I think that may very well make a huge difference. For example, some lines might perform better because they bite into the slack grass blades instead of merely striking them. Some still might be able to get more grass in a single motion because of density or shape. Additionally, as you mentioned yourself, there are other variables to consider. Like the risk of striking things that could damage the line. And here too I think it's likely that shape, material, and weight may make significant differences.

Of course, I think those are outside the scope of a variety science channel to test. We didn't subscribe to a weed eater channel after all ;D

Some key points left out are that the size and weight of the line used has to be matched to the speed and power of the weedeater (Northern California person, and that's the most common name around here lol).
As you showed previously, if you make the line too long it slows the motor down, and the same is true if you put a larger diameter or heavier line on than the motor can pull.
So Robert's unit is most likely much more powerful than yours, and so would have no problem straightening that line out, and possibly also spins at a faster rpm.

The other big reason for using different shape and style lines is line life.
A round line will cut grass just about as well as an equivalent other shaped line, but it wears off on rocks and fences and such much faster. The shapes seem to give it a buffer or wear guard to protect the core longer against debris wear.
It also can make a difference when getting into star thistle, blackberry vines, etc, where a round line just slides off, but a textured line digs in more, and doesn't wear as fast.
I am basing this off experience and logic, so I could be wrong, but it's worth testing lol

"Weed Eater" is the brand name of the first "weed eaters" on the market, or at least the first that were advertised in Alabama (Birmingham) in the early '70s. I think that name, at least in parts of the US, became the name everyone used, kind of like calling all facial tissues Kleenex. This is the answer:
The cleanest cuts will be the result of a 2 corner string also known as a blade, but besides the fladerig of it the chance you hit the grass with the flat side is pretty high.
So putting more corners on the string makes the results more reliable and you wont have a really flat side with which you will cut uncleanly, but also you will have a thicker blade or surface at which you will hit the grass, so it will not cut as clean but also wont Shredder the grass.
so a round string is the most reliable in therms of- not hitting with a flat side, but also you have no sharp edge, since there are no corners but its round...
The circle sacrifices the sharp cut, but at lest doesn't shred every 2nd or 3rd grass by hitting with the flat side, on the other hand the square or triangle can get cleaner cuts, but can also hit with the flat side resulting in a demolition of the grass-thingy.
J would guess that the star shape is exactly in the middle of not complete flat sides and still having some sharper corners to get a good cut.
It can basically only hit with 1 or 2 corners and has no real flat side which would shreds the grass.
But this is only an estimation i found fitting for the results, hope my English isnt toooo bad and soo ;))

7:20 the reason is that there isn`t a "karman vortex street", which is normally formed when you induce a round shape into a flow. It is resposible for the tonal (or small-bandwidth) noise that is audible then. Frequency is mainly depending on the flow velocity and the diameter of the shape. The helical thread around an antenna eliminates this "tonal generation". In the automotive sector this is mainly an comfort-issue, for large chimneys, where this (helical thread) was first introduced it has something to do with stability ^^

- How much grass particles are whipped up (maybe correlated to how cleanly it cuts?) over some patch of grass?
- How long a section of the wire type lasts on average?
- What effect does the mass or thickness have on the various shapes?
And of course, what all of this tells us when we scale up the results to a large field of grass.

Star shape pattern: more points, more likely to have a point as the leading edge. When the concave surface does end up being the leading edge, the void is smaller overall than the voids formed by the concave surfaces on the sharp sharp square. smaller voids on their own will be less likely to retain material. Additionally, the extra 3 points on the star shape create a rounder profile, and as such allow for more deflection when compared to the abrupt 90* profile of each of the sharp sharp square's corners.

My take on the star and sharp square (and I'm by no means an expert so I may be wrong) is you're probably right about the square design funneling the grass into the concave side, as it does very much appear to be doing exactly that.
The star line is doing the same thing except it has four faces or planes contacting the grass as opposed to the one face of the square. The star has two leading planes hitting the grass nearly perpendicular, thus doubling the funneling effect of the square, but just behind those are two more planes that have a much more dramatic offset which would work to push the severed edges of the grass blade apart. Additionally, the star shape also has a single leading point, which would start the cut more cleanly while the four concave planes continue the cleanliness of the cut by gently (well, as gently as 10,000 rpm can be anyway) pushing the severed grass blade apart. The square shape has two leading edges on the top and bottom that cut the grass blade into three distinct parts, the middle of which gets funneled into the single perpendicular concave plane.

I usually go for as thick as i can because i would rather shred than get frustrated at something that wont cut.  Im disappointed the test was on grass. I mean you use the lawnmower for the grass and use the weedeater to shape it because it can cut anything at any angle.  The test should have been on real thick weeds that require at least a good 10 second to cut cleanly.  Thin lines are for people who cut their grass every other day and they pull the weeds before they become problematic. Most people i think would be wasting their money on such a thing because the thicker lines last way longer. I think physically the most efficient system would be a circular wire, though that is dangerous for the potential fire hazard while in use, so cutting efficiency isnt the only thing you think about with this kind of thing. The star pattern seems better simply because it has more "sharp" edges increasing the likelihood that one edge will strike the blade of grass square on. Even though it is more circular than the triangle or sharp squares, I don't believe a large wedge makes a huge difference. It seems that the grass just needs a failure point for which the rest of the tear can be propagated from. This is kind of like duct tape or athletic tape. It can be hard to start a tear on the tape, but once a tear is started, it is easy to rip along that tear. It looks like the star pattern has the highest likelihood to start a tear in the grass with it's many sharp edges, but once the more dull "body" of the wire comes into contact with the blade, it can push along that tear, giving a clean cut.

did years of lawn service, here's my input;
if youre just getting it to upkeep a well manicured lawn of zozia, a smaller diameter round line had the best results that ive used.
if youre cutting a variety of grasses & seedling trees, all the shapes ive tried (triangle, square, stars) have the edges worn off & become cylindrical anyway. they also tend to run at lower rpms (im assuming because of their mass & lack of aerodynamics) another issue is flapping around which causes issues when edging. traditional line gets chewed up too quickly.
the titanium line is the best ive found. it lasts a long time when going through tough stuff & it does pretty well on lawns too.

a couple things I will give warning to is; if you have a softer line & weedeat for an extended period, it tends to melt to itself because the shaft gets so hot (especially in 100 degree weather with 90% humidity lol). that causes feeding issues when you bump it for more line. the titanium line can have this issue too (even though its not soft) because it lasts so dang long.

I was thinking about what you said regarding sharp sharp square line and star line and I was thinking that surface area might be equally as important as linear density and I say this because of the way grass is structures on a cellular level. The cell walls of grass are stacked horizontally in strips of cells but the structure of the cell wall itself is cross hatched. These crossed beams of cellulose are bound by pectin, a structural protein. So what I’m thinking is, is that if these are stacked horizontally, it’s like when people punch layers of wood boards - where, in this case, the grass is reinforced by multiple layers of cell walls. Therefore, although given the same acceleration, a more linearly dense line would provide more force, at least for the square line, it’s doing so over a larger area of grass in a direction in which grass is much more structurally stable. What the star does is take advantage of that. By making contact with essentially 2 wedges on each end of any given point of contact, as well as a much smaller valley in between them, you are causing the grass to bunch up towards a much smaller point, which means it stretches the areas around it length-wise (which goes back to the fact that grass isn’t that strong vertically). Therefore the cellulose bands in the cell walls are stretched as well, making them a lot more structurally unstable, giving you a cleaner cut with the star. Just some thoughts

Just because most people say it a particular way ... that doesn't make it the actual terminology.  "Weed eater" and "weed whacker" are generic trademarks, ie a brand name that's become so synonymous with what they represent that it's become the go-to word for describing that item.  Think "Kleenex" vs "Tissue".  Same thing here.  String trimmer is the actual generic name, while weed eater/weed whacker is the proprietary eponym. I haven't cut apart an antenna to check, but I think this is a case of winning twice. I'd always thought the spiral nature of the antenna wire on a car's was primarily there to increase the electrical length of the antenna without increasing its total height, this is called a "loaded" or "electrically short" antenna, but it looks like it does what I thought and makes it quieter, which I think is pretty cool. More details from initial, off-the-cuff answer below.
If you take apart a handheld radio, especially a cheap one with a ~2"-long antenna, you'll see a thing that looks exactly like a spring. This allows the antenna to resonate at a longer frequency than it would otherwise, at the cost of efficiency (which goes down across the spectrum, but goes up at the resonant frequency of the antenanna) and bandwidth (which becomes narrower). In the US, broadcast radio antennas have to be able to receive signals between 85MHz and 112MHz, which have wavelengths between 3.5m (11.5') and 2.7m (8.9'), respectively. Your classic car antenna will be what's called a "1/4-wave ground plane", indicating that it aims to electrically about 1/4 as long as the wavelength it's designed to receive and that it's using the car's body as a ground plane, which effectively acts as the other half of the antenna. An unloaded, or straight, antenna, would thus be 2.9 feet to 2.2 feet long.

You can see a more extreme version of this in the "shark fin" antennas on newer cars as well as the fact that devices which are smaller than 2" across are somehow able to receive 2.4GHz wi-fi signals.

I literally use the orange star line around the house and just some random thick line for my wood line. I think the star shape is beneficial because it has multiple small sharp points of contact to begin making a cut and it’s a lighter line so it’s more gentle on the push through. The orange star cuts great for regular grass but doesn’t hold up well around concrete edges or chain link fence, it gets eaten. It’s too thin for durability.

Hypothesis: With all the non-star shapes, since they're only triangles/squares at most there is only ever one "edge" slicing through the grass. As we saw with the triangle when the edge lines up perfectly it's a nice clean cut but all too often those shapes are hitting the grass with a flat side, bludgeoning the grass and making it really messy. The star shape on the other hand is always striking with edges instead of flats.

I wonder how much of a factor weight is and length of line. I would assume the faster the line is moving the easier it is to cut, similar to why smaller bullets penetrate more in armor. However, smaller line cannot be to far away from the hub or drag will start to overcome the driving forces. It would also be interesting to see the wind created by these. You would not want line that pushes the grass over before it can be cut. The number of variables involved in what seems like a simple scenario is amazing.

Other things to test:
- how durable each line is. Star might cut the best, but also it might break the most easily
- whether the wrap job affects how the line spins. You claimed sharp sharp square doesn't want to cut in the same plane, but that could have just been a bad wrap job

I always chose plain, simple round monofilament line. With no special profiles or textures. When you make your living with it, you want to limit your downtime and prolong the usefulness of your resources. While sharper profiles may cut cleaner and faster, they are also more brittle and therefore more subject to breaking when they contact hard objects (which are almost always present, or you would have used a mower). I really don't care how cleanly the grass is cut nearly as much as I care about having to waste time and product (money, money, money) replacing it. Structurally, the perfectly round profile is stronger than sharp ones.

It's interesting that you waited until the end of the video to mention lighter vs heavier (density).  It does seem logical that a heavier line would cut weeds better and lighter line would cut grass more evenly.  But you didn't test for durability which for me is the key consideration.  Most people use string trimmers to trim grass or weeds next to concrete edges such as driveways, sidewalks, etc. or around trees or fences.  I really don't care if a weed or blade of grass is cut "clean".  I care about how long the line lasts.  I've tried Rhino Tuff HD (heavy duty), Copperhead Vortex Professional and Grass Gator (all 0.095" diameter) and the Rhino Tuff (triangular shape line) was easily the most durable.  The Copperhead was easily the least durable but it was the most flexible (two round shape lines twisted and fused together to give an hourglass shape) and cut the most evenly but I had to replace the Copperhead line more than twice as much as the Rhino Tuff.  You should make a video on line durability.

Few comments as an daily user (my job) for  over 10 years. Typically the round profile lines last longer than the other shaped styles when purchased in the same string guage, with the squares being a close second. That said the squares seem to leave a more even cut (i mean all grass blades in relation to each other, individually they may shear though often less then the rounds shear them) than the rounds, and hold up fairly well to daily use and do decent on thicker weeds. That stars tend to leave a better cut (individual blades) but often tend to wear quicker. As for the triangles, ive usually seen roughly the same performance as square strings except they are quieter but then again dont last quiiiiiite as long. Ultimately it depends on ure need. Star: well manicured, withough dense weeds, few rocks/fence obstacles. Round: USUALLY economical, long lasting(even with hard obstacles), often louder, and sometimes have to go over same spot a couple times. Square/triangles: basically a middle ground between the two. Not perfect by any means. Doesnt cut as "clean" as star, but usually one pass will do dense weeds, doesnt last as long as round but still long enough to be worth it. Ironically we settled on 2 varieties, 1 of which was the same as ur local trimmer guy. SIDENOTE: that titanium style does seem to last the longest, and not sure if its the real reason, but a few trimmer dealers had said the grooves along its length were to help the "push feed" style trimmer heads be able to better grab the line. Just my 2 cents.

String trimmers and rotary mowers, whilst simple in design and usage, DO reduce the length of your lawn; they also cause your lawn to turn brown, or look dead MUCH quicker. This is due to all of those individual plant fibers being "whacked" and beaten all over the place. For a MUCH better looking and healthier lawn, use "old school" reel-mowers and reciprocating trimmers that use a shearing action to cut the plant fibers. You wouldn't use a "weed-whacker" to cut the hair on your head, would you? Of course not. Think golf courses, baseball diamonds, and football fields. How do you think they keep them so beautiful and healthy-looking? That precise, clean-cut created by the shear, has less area to turn brown and will heal itself much quicker. They also help reduce noise pollution to keep the neighbors happy. Just saying.

The fewer points of interaction the sharper the cord, however the more rotational drag and lower chance of the sharp end hitting the grass. Star counteracts the drag by having enough points to 1) make the drag that effects the upper and lower portion of the cord cancel out, and 2) always have a point facing the grass.

it’s a super crude hypothesis, but at first i assumed the star shaped line cut better and cleaner because of the higher surface area of the “blade” on the line. for example, Robert’s line had sharp edges, but only one on each corner. Like Destin said, it seemed to bunch the grass into the center of the line. However with the star shaped line there is a higher probability that the cutting surface will make direct contact with the blade of grass and make a clean cut. Destin also said that the star appeared to be having the same behavior, but because of this higher probability of direct contact, it is a recessive variable under the cutting surface.

Maybe there's some sort of critical cutting point of the grass.
Circular shape is too round and acts like a blunt blade hence the ripping.
You'd need a sharper surface contacting it which is why myself a maybe a few others thought the triangle would be best because of the sharp points. But sharper points (kept in the same diameter) means less points.
So you'd need more points, we saw the square didn't quite have enough but was better, the star shape seemed best but any more spikes would make it too circular. So it's (if you're keeping the diameter of each weed eater lime the same) getting enough points to consistently like them up in the direction of cutting consistently, but not so many it acts like a circle. If you're goal is clean cuts that is. obviously there's factors like weight and speed but this is all I could gather

FWIW, I reckon it's got something to do with the amount of secondary contact between the grass and the line. It looks to me like when a flat side of the line strikes the grass flush it seems to break though cleanly, but when a pointy edge strikes the grass first, it winds up shedding the grass. Makes me think that the front of the line probably always breaks the grass fairly cleanly, and it's the sides that shred the grass as they pass along the freshly cut edge. The cleanest cut will occur therefore if the leading edge is fat and the trailing edge is thin.

What this means is that the ideal line should be faceted. The ideal number of facets is a bit hard to figure though. If you have too few facets the chance of hitting the grass somewhat edge on is high which will expose the grass to the sides of the line and shred the grass (ie the triangle). But if the number of facets is too high, the facet will be too small and thus also expose the grass to the sides of the line (ie the circle).
If you are cutting harder stuff, buy a brush cutter head. Far better for brambles etc

in regards to shape the shorter distance between nodes on the star, compared to the square, may be whats causing the cleaner cut.

There's so much more to it than just the way it cuts.
But Robert is the smarter guy here, he knows the star shaped one gives you better efficiency for cutting.

My own initial thought was that a golf ball shape (dimples) would be the fastest, most silent and clean cutting line.
But that isn't always desirable, sometimes you want a mulcher that turns the cut grass into fine mist and for that you would definitely use a sharp square line. While it won't make as clean cuts it will ensure the clippings fall through the standing grass and settles on the bottom giving you a nicer looking "lawn" or strip.
And it really does depend on how heavy the stuff you are cutting is.

In an optimal scenario, you would have a leading and lower down star shaped line and then the sharp square line following it at 10-20 degrees at a higher elevation to mulch up the top you just cut off.
Sure, it would require more power to spin that around at a good speed but it would leave clean cuts and basically no leftover clippings.

And if you really want to get into the science of cutting grass, you should go to a PGA (golf) course. They are able to tell you everything you need to know.
And their mowers will ALWAYS collect the clippings leaving nothing but straight cut grass that is cut to a very specific height without tearing.

My observations
The thicker, square or triangle type lines have more surface to them. If you watch the footage, there is a lot of the surface area striking the fibers in the blades of grass. In this case you are getting a rip or a tear because it is taking a strike a broad edge of grass fibers.
With the star shape, it is more uniform with the edges and it has about two or three of the 'bursts' or projections that hit and cut at slimmer portions of grass fibers, making a cleaner cut. I think this is the reason the star shape has a cleaner tear, and a better rotation because it is not twisting and forcing a blunt line through the air as far as the aerodynamics are concerned.
To better illustrate, it is like swinging a club or bat at a piece of bamboo. You are going to hit a lot of fibers of bamboo all at once, giving it a smack, and causing a rip or a tear. It will take a few swings, and will not take a clean cut.
Conversely, a sharpened blade like a machete or sword blade will not hit as many fibers of bamboo, and will slice through much easier and in fewer swings.
This is just my layman explanation, I am not sure what you make of it, Destin. I'd be happy to hear your take on this and see if it is a thought that you considered.

I've done a fair bit of whipper snipper work commercially, and the thinnest round line to match your skill level seems to be best.

By best I mean:
1) most accurate (no deviance in where each line hits like with the "sharp square"
2) cleaner cuts in the same way that a very thin/acutely bevellee knife cuts cleaner
3) less loss of head speed under actual use (thicker lines bog down more as more of the force is transferred to the thick grass)
4) more reliable bump-feed operation

If you're inexperienced, you'll run thin line into stuff like concrete edgeing and lose a bunch of line to breaks really quickly, but that's not what happens when you've got some hours up.

I have also noticed that the quality of the line at a give thickness makes a huge difference in durability, and given how variable plastic is in general; that's always made sense to me.

Just like an "all purpose knife" isn't actually feasible, a line (or brush cutter head) should be matched to the job. A sushi knife excels at its job, but can't cut through bones like a cleaver can.

i run my own lawn care business and i run echo black diamond weeder string and like it a lot more than say echo crossfire but that all ive tried, the black diamond stays straight for edging and cuts more under load than the crossfire, you didnt realize a variable
weeder string comes in different with i run .95 but theirs a lot more like.65, .105, .130 dont mix them in the test
Edit: smaller string will always cut better, you can have string as small as a needle to cut grass and it will cut well and clean but its not durable, pros use thicker string because it last longer because its not wearing down / breaking on everything, ive got a really powerful trimmer that i run .130 in because it breaks .95 really easy but the .130 can strip bark of trees so its destructive with power so its a a trade off,
the way i view good trimmer line is not about cut quality ( weed eaters dont have cut quality) but instead the line will power through a mass of grass and hold its straightness and not dig and the durability because when you are replacing the string thats down time of course the echo speedfeed trimmer head helps that a lot over a stranded sthil head but its still down time and time is money

Not a rant. I hope this helps. A couple things to consider. I’ve hear round line is the best for prolonged use because if you start off with it and a shaped line of the same max diameter, what happened Is the last inch n a half gets worn to round. So once the shape is worn down you are essentially using a round line of a smaller size. Secondly (and it’s no rip on Robert) but the plastic that Stihl uses is hydroscopic. So as it dries out it becomes more brittle. So the line that was in the back of Roberts truck may have dried out to a degree preventing it from flattening out as the head turned. As a Stihl dealer I hope this helps and I love seeing your videos, Destin

I think the reason the star pattern "cut" the cleanest, is that it is almost impossible for it to strike the grass with a flat face. The most surface area theoretically possible for it to strike with would be 2 of the ridges at the same time. Even so, that case still has much less surface area contacting the grass at any given time. This means theoretically there should be less energy transferred to the grass, and therefore less peripheral damage to the grass.

I'd like to see the different string weights against the chain link, to see if the heavier ones stand up better. another test (and my main use for the weed wacker) would be how various lines stand up to "scrubbing" or wearing away against the cement driveway as I'm edging the sidewalk. I'm curious about whether the difference in the size of the groove in the sharp sharp square and star lines is responsible for the difference in the quality of the cut. It seems possible that the smaller groove is bunching up a narrower band of the grass thereby concentrating the sheer stress in a narrower band resulting in a cleaner cut.

Alternatively there is also a higher likelihood of the blade of grass being struck by an edge with the star line compared to the sharp sharp square which would obviously also cut better than a blunt side.

It would be interesting to see other types of leaf subjected to the same test as the size of the segments of the blades of grass might influence the cut of each line.

I prefer for "heavy load", so high grass and much stuff to cut the metal blades. Metal blades rock:
- cutting much better everything, espeicially thicker things
- much more silent than lines
- not that much rpm needed at all, i can use the "Eco" Mode on our husquarna 36V battery scythe to cut everything (here in Austria we call the "big boy" tools "Sense", so scythe, and "Trimmer" are the small backyard tools for "the wife")

He had it right on the first statement about the line being a lot quieter. Weed Eaters (Whipper Snippers here in Australia) when they came out in the late 60's early 70's, were mostly electric, (power cord, not battery) it was soon discovered that dogs would try and attack and bite the line heads.The non rounded shape lines appeared shortly afterwards and were marketed as dog or pet saving. The idea that they cut better came as a different marketing strategy a few decades later, as much of a difference we can see magnified and in slow motion, any difference in the finished cut it is not really noticeable to the human eye, regardless of the shape of the line. Line weight and size matter most.

I think Robert's observation that weed eater speed is important is dead on.  I've tried several brands / varieties / shapes / thicknesses and found that on one electric weed eater I use you can tell the difference in the aerodynamic properties in the different string shapes from the vibration the head produces while operating.  That kind of subtlety can't be discerned with a gas trimmer.  One thing I've always wanted to do was use a variable speed drive motor and high speed photography to determine at what speed the best string has the most stable flight path.  I use a star shaped string now because the cut grass looks like it was trimmed with scissors and not ripped apart like a highway department sickle bar mower!

I am going to leave this comment here only because I notice behavioral traits in you Destin that strike a chord with me because I have them myself and I think its interesting. You may or may not feel the same way. If not, feel free to scroll by or delete. This is deep stuff here that most certainly is not appropriate for a YouTube Comment, but here goes:
I noticed you really enjoy incorporating in blue collar folk and you seem to go over the top in making them feel intelligent and equal to (or perhaps greater than) yourself. I see it here with Robert (making him an expert, thinking his choice in line was best immediately, saying things like "we should make Robert in charge of this video!"), and in past videos (the one that comes to mind is the one about grain bins with the farmers). While this is indeed humbling, it is all too familiar to my own behavior. I also would go out of my way to make blue collar folk feel superior to me in smarts. I have a Ph.D. from Penn State and my background is in quantum sensing and applied electromagnetics. I would say things like, "I have more respect for you guys doing the REAL work out there than any of the people I work with." Or even just treat them like they were all knowing when they told me something (even if I knew they were wrong). I would even become very angry when people suggested educated folks are in any way superior/more knowledgeable than them. I made it clear that I am on THEIR side.
What I have come to find out for me personally, is that these behaviors are the result of a "father wound." My father was NOT educated, and was not ever highly achieved. He didn't know better and was never able to teach me anything useful in life (for the most part). I learned early in life that I was more capable than him and developed a codependent type of relationship where I take care of him emotionally to never make him feel lesser. Since as a child, father = all men in the world, and mother = all women in the world, this led to me acting codependent towards other people who reminded me of my dad in some way (blue collar folk) and I would go over the top to make them feel important and better than me. All of this is parent-child role reversal and is actually no good for personal growth (namely, the dad is supposed to make the child feel important, not the other way around). In reality, its a longing from your childhood self to have the dad you never had, one that knows better and can teach you things about the world.
Again this is my story, but I just wanted to comment about it again because I find behavior (my own especially) fascinating. It took lots of books and work to realize all this about myself, and when I see similar behavior in others it gets my attention and sometimes actually helps me learn more.
Take care!

To reduce line welding I anneal the line in hot water. Basically cut line to length and put in a sink full of hot water. After annealing I hang the line with weights so it cools straight.
I used to have to fix the line often, like 3x an hour. When using annealed line I am often able to use a full load of line without the line needing attention.

Okay so what I think is happening for the star shaped wire is that with more points radiating out from the center there is multiple things happening/that could happen. First off with more radiating points you are more likely to hit on a point which with more pressure condensed into a smaller area allowing it to essentially penetrate the edge of the grass then split it in two as the two sides are forced down the slopes on either side of the point. A second possibility/think that could happen is that the it hits on the flat side and forces it into the center of the slope/canyon where it then splits as the pressure from the wire breaks the tensile strength of the portions of grass that are within the trough/slope
Edit: btw watching on my ps4 and responding on my phone before robert gives his oppinion
Edit: Also being the second lightest line it will possibly have less drag/resistance in the air possibly allowing it to spin and cut better while also requiring less power over time to keep spinning

Hey Dustin, as an engineer for outdoor handheld power products, I’d like to first start by saying it’s a “String Trimmer.” The reason I believe we call them weed eaters is because that was one of the first we’ll-known brand names for string trimmers back in the 1970’s. The weed eater brand is currently owned by Poulan, which makes other brands of outdoor power equipment. As for the trimmer line, we test with round line and what we call twist line, which is the tri-color line you showed. The reason for both is the round line has a higher load on the engine, because of the higher air resistance. Some engines don’t like high rpm’s, so we usually use round line on those. Additionally, the length of the line helps load the engine more, so extending the “swath” to 17”, or 8.5” per side (from the center of rotation) usually loads the engine well. If the engine is running too slow, we bring the swath in, and of it isn’t enough, we switch the line to twist line. I really enjoy your content! Keep up the amazing work.

VPNs don't do what they market themselves to do! The little Lock symbol in your address bar to the left of your link means that you've established a successful SSL connection. SSL means that your own device is auto-encrypting everything it sends to that website, and only they can decrypt it. It has to do with one-way-maths, which might seem intimidating, but it's really quite simple to understand the concept. Tom Scott has a very informative video on this subject.
The "tunnel" you talked about at 13:33 is what SSL is already doing for you, the VPN is literally just giving it another server to bounce off of. Destin, if you see this, please look into this! It's something that I would really think you should be properly informed about.

Idk if anyone has already said this or mentioned it but, it's all aerodynamics. Let's say you have a vehicle that a tow rack on top of it (usually aftermarket) and it's installed horizontal on top of your vehicle meaning it goes left to right from driver to passenger door and not front to back. When the vehicle gets up to enough speed the wind will cause it to vibrate up and down. Sorry let me back up if the rail is round or squared. Not the wind will hit it causing an up force and down force. That's why an airplanes wings are shaped the way the are so that the wind can pass over and cause and up force for lift. Long story short I'm running out of room. If you take 550 cord or something and wrap in a spiral around your wrack. It will stop the noise which is vibration. That's why the strings have the spirals in them for aerodynamics and sound.

As someone who does lawn care, it less about how clean the cut is, and way more about how durable it is. When you have to add line 30 + times a day, you want the most durable stuff out there.

While I totally understand the point of isolating a single grass with a single, similar tension, this should not be the end of it. Ultimately you want what works best on the lawn/bush. One with less edges may be more resistant over time; one shape may be better to grasp on a loose leaf; as you said one with density would be stronger on bush; etc. Even down to the color may affect the cleanness of your cut (i.e if you're more able to see your orange line rather than a grey one).
I think the set-up you have is good to compare similar stuff (i.e which square one is giving a cleaner cut) or if you'd aim to improve on one design - and the totally cool slow-mo videos - but to compare wider range of shapes you'd want to ultimately test it in the real environment, with untied grass.
Also, given what came out of it (esp. your comment on the stiffness of weed-eater dude's string), measuring the tensile strength of each one is totally worth a quicky on SED2, complementing the density discussion :p
