I know this test was specifically to determine which line makes the cleanest cut, but there's way more to it than that, especially for professional landscapers. Some of the lines that pulverize the grass are actually beneficial because it creates a mulching of sorts, allowing the trimmed grass to feed the love grass. Of course, this is not what you want for all types of grass, but it is beneficial for some. You already made the observation that some line is better for brush as well, and there's also the issue of noise and durability over time. I'm not an expert on any of this, but boy did I get an earful about it growing up from my dad's friend, who was a professional landscaper in Decatur, AL. I helped him a couple of summers but only for the cash. I knew that wasn't the job for me 😂

Long term extended use experience.
It isn't about cutting.
Nobody cares how well it cuts the grass.
it is a combination, durability / defectiveness.
A valid test, would be 1/2 in dowel, vs a full (to guard) length of line.
Test to see how far through the dowel it will cut, before the line is broken to a point where it is unusable.
The trade off for these "high test" heavy, sharp lines,
is when you strike a wooden fence, or siding, it does damage.

You want a line, that isn't destroyed while edging (vertical trimming, next to the concrete) while not having it do damage to structures.

Also, the helical structure you noted on your car aerial is called a strake, or helical strake and they're designed to reduce vortex induced vibration caused by vortex shedding. You'll find them on all sorts of tubular or cylindrical objects that are designed to flow through a fluid, or have a fluid flow around them. For example you'll often see them on smoke stacks, usually near the top where the wind could cause damaging vibrations.

I believe the shape is not so important as the actual radius of the contacting surface. I expect the "best" line would be one that optimally balances its mass and its diameter. Shaped lines that have points would seem intuitively like the best bet since they would have a sharp edge to cut with, but as you noted in the video, to have corners means to have flat surfaces between them, and the radius of a flat surface would approach infinity. I think that having these shaped cross-sections might help with trade-offs, one way or the other, but I think the "optimal" line would be perfectly cylindrical, with a low enough diameter as to truly cut the grass, and a high enough mass to physically drive the cut. You also mentioned the stiffness as a factor, in how it cuts in two places, I don't think that should have much bearing on the clean-ness of a cut (unless you want to minimise pieces of grass cut at the midsection of the blade). It would probably affect your cutting "flow" to have to think about two cutting planes, or effectively only use half of your cutting line if the higher line never gets to make contact with the grass. Maybe it's too dangerous, but what about testing with metal wire instead of the plastic? It should be flexible enough to straighten itself out after hitting grass, though might be ruined by hitting a hard object like a fence... Still, metal being more dense than plastic, I think comparing metal and plastic of equal diameters would show that density (or rather, total mass) matters more than cross-sectional profile. Also, though harder to test, line materials that have different diameters with equal mass, the lower diameter lines should cut better for a given mass. Like, imagine whacking the weeds with a pool noodle vs razor wire (not that these would have equal masses for a given length of line, but you get the idea)

Was a gardener for years, my thoughts. Professional line isnt generally sold in hardware stores and is gonna want a professional grade tool, might distribute the line more evenly.
But more importantly, cleanness of cut is nowhere near the first consideration you should make for line. Doesnt matter how fine the grass is, you only use it in places the line will be hitting fence/brick etc. Somewhere a mower wont reach. You want the line that lasts longest, always. Grass is hardy af and loves a haircut anyway. Dont do it when its super hot out and the messy cuts mean nothing.

right near the end you talked about the diameter of the line which makes a big difference depending on the type of trimmer you have, like that 2.4mm line wouldn't work well at all in a small electric trimmer (found out thru personal experience), but at the same time a finer line would wear out too quickly in a heavy duty petrol trimmer but would cut really well (high speed + small surface area). If the line is too heavy for the trimmer it can't get up to speed.

Something you didn't test was what is the optimal length of line to pay out. I operated a weed trimmer in my younger years and one of the considerations to take into account was how fast the line shortened towards the spool housing the line. The shorter it got the faster the head could spin, to a certain extent. If it got too short it would spin really fast but cut ineffectively simply because there wasn't enough line out. Most weed trimmers have a guard that deflects flying grass and other objects away from the operator's feet as even a weed trimming line can propel a small object very fast. The guard usually also trims the line ends so that they're approximately the same length, usually by having the line hit a piece of metal designed to shear off the line at the desired length. If the guard gets out of position you might end up with line that's too long and costing more fuel because of the fact that it's trying to spin more mass on the end of the trimmer line. You should always test with the recommended and optimal line length for the trimmer.

The star has edges, but unlike the square and triangle, it has no flat surfaces.  Its 7 points ensure one of the following:  1.  Two sharp edges hit the grass at the same time, first followed by two more edges (top, and bottom), 2. one sharp edge hits straight on. followed by two mid way up the curve (top and bottom),  followed by two more trailing edges (top and bottom), or 3. Some orientation between the two, which would also always ensure  that some edges pass across top and bottom.

The mass and stiffness also effects the maximum useful diameter of material to be cut, so if he can perform a greater variety of tasks with the same tool and trimmer line, he's gaining efficiency there as well. Effective kerf width depends on aerodynamic stability of the line being spun. The star shape is the farthest away from cylindrical without any flat faces and probably generates a ton of totally uniform turbulence that keeps it spinning in a nearly perfectly flat disc, like a rigid saw blade. Circular cross section is among the worst aerodynamic shapes going and most likely to do the semi-chaotic bifurcation "dance" as the forces collapse and rebuild around either side of its direction of travel, pushing it up and down the axis of rotation. Triangular, as Destin says, has flat faces that also cause chaotic movement. Cutting thin but cellulosic grass needs a thin, precise and high speed, blade for best results.

I think i might have an idea why the star one is such a clean cut in comparison to the others, though i struggle a bit to bring it to words so bare with me; Image hanging a rope from the ceiling with something weighing it down (sort of similar what you did with the grass blades) and you were to slap it. There is alot of surface area that is acting with force upon the rope and you can see that in how the rope react and in the feedback you feel in your arms, it's kinda chaotic. Now if you were to hit it again but with the smaller side of a flat hang (pinky first) you get a less chaotic pattern in the rope and it is clearer where the rope gives way for the force you project on it. Now if you do this again, but at two points at the same time, you get the same result at the points of impact, but there is space in the middle that the force doesn't effectively disperse to since you hit it with so little surface area. If you put these two point closer together, then eventually you'll find the sweet spot where the center does give way and act sort of the same as the two places of impact, which should make it a pretty clean push. I think that the star shaped line achieves just this thus making it a much cleaner cut then all the more blunt lines.

I have tried every type of line over many years, and there are many variables to consider.
A very big factor, only touched upon here, is the diameter of the line. The quality of the material is also very important.
The larger the diameter, the more durable it is, but it cuts less efficiently (like a blunt blade). It also spins less efficiently, and makes less powerful machines struggle and thus puts more stress on them.
Smaller diameter lines wear out quicker, but spin up and spin down quicker, and they put less loading on the machinery. They cut like a sharper blunt blade, but have to be kept spinning faster.
It's all about physics, trial and error for your working conditions, and the type of machine you are using.
Also of note is that the squarer type often jam in the auto feed system, which is a real pain...
My favourite for a 50cc professional machine is 2.7mm diameter round, but twisted. No auto feed jamming, and the twist makes a big cutting difference compared to standard round.

The spiral on the antenna is a the same as the spirals on tall chimneys, it's used to eliminate vortex shedding that can cause oscillation. The same idea is also used on airplanes where it's called a strake.

Those spirals around car antennas are meant to prevent vortex induced vibrations and are called "Scruton-Coils". They are commonly used on tall smokestacks and on suspension bridge wiring. They break up wind-pockets and prevent them from resonating in the frequency range of the structure.

If I had to make a guess, I'd say the star is most likely to apply the greatest force to single points. The triangle had the steepest points, but there are only three, so the odds of catching a point is lower than the star. The star had the most points, so you have a higher likelihood of actually striking with the point.

It's the same way knives work. You sharpen an edge so the force you apply to that edge is magnified tremendously. The star line has a higher chance of applying that effect.

There's probably a better way to explain this, but this is my guess.

What cuts best is the thickest line that your trimmer head will take,   it wont be the most efficient and it wont necessarily produce the healthiest result but it will cut the best. .105 will last the longest between refills, it will cut grass, weeds, small saplings, even larger trees if you are patient.  It will also cut vinyl siding, cable tv/internet coax cable, ground bonding wire,  wooden fence slats, garden hoses, pvc water pipe,  and will sling a tree branch or a toy 100 feet to take out the neighbor's window, or your helper's eye. Safety gear strongly advised.   It all depends on how much power you have on your trimmer, what kind of stuff you are trying to cut,  what you are going to hit that you dont want to cut,  and experience level.  For a homeowner, with a homeowner quality trimmer, stick to the thinner line.  I use mid power commercial trimmer and have done it a LOT. My personal best compromise is .09  Whatever line you choose store it in water and it will last a lot longer and give you less trouble.

The most impactful variable in this experiment was the speed with which the weed eater approached the grass and since this wasn't controlled, the results don't mean much. This is because the grass offered very little resistance; all of the lines had the potential to cut through them first time if a sufficient length of it hit the grass. A better experiment would have had the lines cut through something with much greater resistance, enough to stop some of them but allow others or at least have a quantitative result (such as the depth of an incision into a thicker piece of material).

I'd be very interested if you tried this experiment properly, Destin. My hypothesis is that the line with the greatest mass would have the greatest 'cutting' power (given that the area with which it made contact stayed constant). Otherwise, I'd say the shape has negligible impact on the performance of the _strimmer_.

Spiral line is sold by stihl as a low noise line.

Still tells you that as their plastic in higroscopic you should leave it submerged in watef 24hours to increase its resistance. I guess its because it increases its density.

Customers that maintain a massive private neighborhood uses 2.4mm line even tho their equipment (FS280) is rated to use a 2.7mm line bacause they say you can maintain more speed on the trimmer head and you have cleaner cuts with it because its more stable.

What I notice as a small garden equipment tech is that the cutting part of a trimmer head is the extreme part of it, the points. And when you cut for a few minutes every line becomes round because of erosion. So you notice more benefit in trimmer line resistance to erosion than you notice in the actual cross section of the line.

I also notice that some weird shape line pulverizes grass, it explodes it and cover you in grass juice but that doesnt mean it cuts faster, it just means the line wonders and hits more surface. That means that every time it hits the grass, it starts a new cut, so you waste energy. For example, its like using a very wide chainsaw chain. If you just want to cut a branch, why removing a wide section of it? You want to go through, not across. That principle is used on electric and battery chainsaws to increase its performance: they use thin chains. Of couse theres a compromise between thickness of cutting element and its wear resistance so you dont see extremely thin chain on bigger chainsaws meant for productivity.

If you mow yards for a living and get good at it. You have to be a master at making observations. Time is money. If you can observe and find the most efficient techniques then you get more yards done and make more money. That being said, I cringe when I see 95% of people try to weed eat. They don't realize how inefficient they are. A normal size residential yard takes most people 20-30 minutes to trim when it can be done in less than 5. Here is my thinking about this problem:

To have a clean cut, you want your string to cut faster then the speed of sound inside the grass when it breaks. This speed depends on the linear elasticity and mass of the grass, and the tension exercés by the string at the moment the grass breaks.

Hence, having a clean cut depends on having a heavy string that goes fast, the shape only actes on the speed. And I think your star shape string takes adventage of the golf ball effect, which is not the case for the other strings.

In college I worked doing a ton of weedeating, mostly areas that mowers couldn’t get (because the ground was perpetually too wet) and slopes that were too steep, as well as edging. In my experience round is the best for a few reasons:

1) All line wears out pretty fast, and as it wears the shape goes away so the shape no longer matters
2) The increased sound you get from it is extremely useful for pacing how fast the head is actually spinning
3) It doesn’t get bound up and tangled in the head as easily

The star line is the runner up for me though.

I think the reason the star pattern cuts the best is that its surface is dimpled.  Dimpled surfaces, like on golf balls or modern airplane wings, prevent atmospheric layer separation and make the air wrap around the back of the object, which reduces its drag.  This probably makes the star-pattern line cut the best because it is the most straight.

What I would assume is likely to happen, is that with the triangular shape, if the grass is struck with a corner, a lot of pressure is put on one point. That results in a clean cut. If the grass is struck with the blunt edges, it will rip the grass apart rather than cutting it cleanly. In the star shape however, there are more of those sharp corners, therefore, the chance of the wire hitting the grass with one of said corners is much higher and thus it yields a clean cut more often than in the triangle's case. It might not always do that however, there's just not enough data right now to draw a conclusion.

Hey Destin! Robert could not have come at a more opportune time. The additional revolutions on the lighter lines is an excellent observation. But I think the star line outperformed the others also because of the numerous cutting edges on it. I worked at a farm equipment shop for a while and was taught to sharpen brush hog blades flat on the leading edge. Instead of having one sharpened edge, the flat grind created two cutting edges. The six points of the star line have two cutting edges each. The star line's twelve cutting edges give a higher likelihood of a cut rather than a tear. (Sorry I said cutting edges a lot. But I digress, cutting edges.)

I'm not using weet eater so often, but in my humble mechanical engineers opinion Robert is partly right: if all of the lines are made out of the same material, then the thickness matters a lot. More mass means less velocity with the same force (more RPM with the weed eater). But thiner diameter means less tensile strength, so it will break more often. It would be interesting if a Material with lower density and higher tensile strength  would be even better. e.g. glass fiber, carbon fiber, human or horse hair, spider web?

Decades ago I was working summers at a local city gardening department in Finland and used a weed eater quite a lot. We first used a plain round line, but later saw that a star-shaped line was available and so we tried it. My final conclusion was that maybe the star shaped one cuts thin grass a little better but all in all you don't want to be changing the line type and therefore we just continued using the round one because it was much more durable than the star shaped (if I remember correctly it was an even more pronounced star shape than the one tested in this video). And with general grass you cannot really see any difference in the cut unless you specifically look for it with a magnifying glass or microscope!

My theory is that the aerodynamics on the string is what's responsible for the orientation of the string, ergo, it wants to present the smallest frontal surface area in relation to the circular motion. In the case of the triangluar string, point forwards or flat side forwards doesn't matter, but in the case of the square and star lines it does. With the square line, the flat side is forwards because that presents the smallest frontal surface area. With the star line, the same principal applies, but because it is star, it still has a point hitting the grass first, creating a cleaner cut.

Hypothesis: As the line spins around the center of the weed wacker, it would also twist as is passes through air based on its shape. Maybe the start pattern line, having more 'edges' would twist faster, like a fan blade almost. This twisting allows more edge - grass contact, and lest pocket/flat side - grass contact as it passes through the blade of grass, thus creating a cleaner cut. I think that the star line acts more like a saw blade than the other lines.

I’ve been weedeating for 20 years. I’ve used all kinds of line and the star twist .95 is my choice. When I buy a weedeater the first thing I do is take the guard off. When you get more line out it cuts better. I think the tip of the line is moving a lot faster. Also the way to know when you have enough line out is by the sound of the engine. There’s a sweet spot that keeps the rpm high but has more line out than factory recommends. And the reason for the guard is not because that’s the best length of line. It’s there to cut the line to a certain length so the clutches don’t wear prematurely. These videos have been awesome to watch. Thanks.

The experiments proved one thing to me; none of the lines actually cut!  At best they whip their way through the grass using their accelerated mass to break through the blades of grass.  Of course, Mass X Acceleration = Force.  Therefore, the lines don't cut through the grass as much as they force their way through the grass.  Less mass (lighter weight line) yields more acceleration, as Robert said, to maintain the force needed.  Yet, in heavier/thicker grass or weeds, the acceleration bleeds off quickly and the line loses the force necessary and then relies on the torque of the engine to force its way through the grass.  In the process of transition from acceleration to torque, the drag on the slower line speed produces increased drag on the engine and it loses its efficiency.

How well a given shape cuts is irrelevant.  None are going to cut as clean as a reel mower and thus will all leave some jagged brown edges.  The bigger problem with weed eater line is how easily it gets chewed up by hard surfaces, fencing, etc.  For 80% of the use case for a weed eater, it's up against obstacles that you couldn't reach with your mower.  Those obstacles chew up the line.  Project Farm already tested different lines to find the best overall in a variety of categories.  Especially informative in his video was strength against obstacles.

I think the shape is irrelevant, it's down to the diameter and how powerful your strimmer is.

I also have a issue with the experimental design. I understand wanting to eliminate uncontrollable variables, but the aerodynamic properties of the trimming medium matter for real world applications.
I use aeroflex blades, they are arranged to create an updraft, which I can feel pulling the trimmer head down. The advantage here in theory is that the updraft pulls the grass up into the blades. Also the blades are plastic blades, the narrow edge always hits the grass.
I would buy triangle just because it gets the job done, but is a lot quieter.

I think the star does better because it increases the chance of an edge-on collision with the grass (or at least be close to it), thus initiate a clean cut rather than bluntly plowing through and causing delamination. Even if it has a suboptimal impact angle, such as a flat-face collision, it would be a smaller area initially striking the grass, thus reducing the impulse transferred which causes the delamination.

Of course, there could be other factors involved such as the line’s helical shape contributing to an increased cutting efficiency. Plus, my argument doesn’t really hold up well when you compare it with similar phenomena occurring like a wadcutter bullet.

Those are almost flat-faced bullets used for paper target shooting. Despite the blunt appearance, they leave clean holes. Perhaps the star shape performs a similar effect better than a sharp square, resulting in better cuts.

A shape ripping the grass apart with force(m x a) is what's happening.  The shape here probably doesn't matter much since the grass is so weak against the force of any string here, it will be ripped apart no matter what.  But, the shape may affect how the line interacts with the grass-section when it rips through it.  The star-shaped line may have a better "Grab" or friction against the grass blade since there are many small points of contact that's mostly aimed at the grass blade than any of the other lines, resulting in more damage.  More, smaller pressure points over time vs a singular large pressure point.

The triangular and square lines are supposed to provide an edge to cut the grass, but Destin's right that more often then not the broad side strikes and rips the grass. In this case the obvious answer is the correct one; the star-shaped line just has more points, and so no matter how it turns, it will always present a sharp point to the grass blade. Even though that point only protrudes slightly past its neighbors, the acute angle is enough to cut the grass.

One of the other considerations for a weed wacker (NJ represent!) is if it moves the grass and debris out of the way. The heavier weight and slightly slower speed can carry the cut grass out of the way as it falls. The smaller diameter can get a cleaner cut and cut the grass multiple times as it falls mulching the grass where it falls. So it's really dependent on what you're looking to do. If you want to cut the grass and then leave it where it lays, the smaller diameter sounds like the better choice. But if you want to remove it from where you're cutting and make it easier to rake up, the larger diameter will clear where you're cutting and leave larger pieces for you to gather up. That's been my experience at least.

I think you may be discounting the cored stuff since you miss out one factor, wear. With the cored stuff, if the core is denser/stronger, you will tend to have a small section at the tip that is just core with the sheath worn off, this thinner denser part may cut better, while the rest of the strand adds overall strength and momentum.
Regarding the star and sharp sharp square I think that pulling you are seeing may be giving you that sharper cut as it maintains tension in the leaf right at the cutting point.

I think the star is less orientation dependent, meaning it will have a more consistent cut compared to squares or triangles, but it has edges which make it a cleaner cut than the circle. From an optimization perspective, you’d get the best “optimal” cut from a triangle (the polygon with the least number of edges) but suboptimal cuts will be the worst of all. By comparison, the circular wire (theoretically a “polygon” with infinite edges) will cut extremely consistently but the cuts will be less clean. Number of edges is directly proportional to consistency of cuts, but inversely proportional to cleanness of “optimal” cuts.

Without wanting to criticise Dustin in any way, shape or form:

A more rigorous method of testing might be to mount the weed eater, camera, and an electric motor onto the trolley, go to a football field or similar where there's lots of turf/uniform grass, and try each line. You could set a slow, medium and fast speed of the trolley, and see which line is able to do the cleanest cut over a set distance.

This should reduce the problem of lack of grass blade numbers/uniformity, and also show how efficient each string is: a string that can cut grass cleanly at 5mph will be superior to that which cuts up to 3mph before starting to miss blades of grass.

Using that same method you could also see how far you can go before the string breaks - how often you have to change the stuff would definitely be a deciding factor.

One last thing: I'd love to see steel wire tested (obviously with precautions and a big disclaimer not to do this at home!)

I used to mow 20-30 lawns a day for a mowing business. I tried many different types of lines to see how they cut. The smaller, thinner, round-er lines spin at a much higher RPM at max throttle allowing them to get nice clean cuts on thin and well maintained grass. But the heavier, thicker, star shaped lines cut best for thicker, not-as-maintained grass. I had two heads I would switch back and forth from depending on the yard. That star shaped line you had is actually the exact line I used to use. After a few months of switching, I stayed using the star line because I noticed with my weed eater (the right way to say it), spinning slower and being thicker caused the line to break less often and I didn't have to purchase as much of it.  That exact star brand is my go-to, I've probably purchased miles of that stuff over the years.

I CUT BERMUDA. As you can imagine, it’s very thick and needs a line a bit sharper and stronger.💪
I won’t say what brand I use, but it’s VERY similar to the “Star shape”, but it’s a “sharp spiral”.
Why? HERE IS WHY:
The spiral reduces drag, thus increases rpm efficiency to permit the most hours of force. (Think of bullet ballistics). Being sharp, that faster, more energy behind a sharp edge allows a cleaner cut and decreases the number of hits to do so. The more edges means the better odds of a sharp side being the initial contact.
On Bermuda grass, we don’t RIP our lawns with rotary mowers. We use REEL (or “cylinder” mowers. They CUT the grass like a pair of scissors, instead of ripping the grass with a machete in a vacuum cleaner (sorry rotary mower people🙏).
The more sides, the better odds a “sharp” side contacts. Sharp means cleaner cut. Twisted means reduced drag and thus faster and more power is transferred to the “sharp edge”.
MATERIAL plays part on the wear and tear, as well as how fast it dulls. Trust me, with Bermuda, I go through A LOT, but my lawn looks beautiful.
I reel mow the entire thing, but we still need to TRIM sides, around tight spots, the mailbox, etc.

I hope this helps. Speed, sharp and ODDS of sharp are the key to what I use.

When I was doin' lawn care as a job, I ended up testing three different types of line. In most cases, it seemed like diameter played the biggest role in cutting power (and stress on my poor old weed eater motor) relative to brush density, as with smaller lines, pushing too quickly into a particularly tough stem would just wrap the line around it and reduce RPM, preventing the weed eater head from getting back up to a cutting speed without backing up to reset. Also because if its durability, it took almost twice as long to go through the thick stuff. 2-3 jobs, vs 1 refill per job with the thinner stuff!

With that in mind, I found that thinner lines let me get cleaner looking edges around houses or sensitive surfaces. Thin line tends to sheer off or break when in close contact with a hard surface, such as a metal fence, concrete, synthetic siding, or a tree as opposed to cutting deeply into the surface, which allowed for a wider margin of error when trimming these areas. Additionally, if at lower RPMs, thin line was flexible enough in tight spaces to just... well, make a horrible sound, but also flay any grass without causing damage to the surfaces of the space itself.

Fluid dynamics will play a significant role in the behavior, won't it?
There's certainly merit in knowing which line has a better potential of cutting cleanly but I think angle of approach is going to influence the true effectiveness of the line. The behavior of whatever we're trying to cut will influence that. In the last video, you commented on how the direction of approach is meaningful due to the direction of travel of the line and also the grass. In this video, you commented on the aerodynamics of the triangular line making the line quieter (presumably allowing the line travel faster and the engine having reduced load from the line itself).
Grass doesn't stay upright and I doubt it's under that much tension for any appreciable amount of time. Does grass tend to mostly stay bent toward or away from the line on a given side or does it behave more like a whacky waving inflatable tubeman? Does the shape of the line have a meaningful influence on this behavior?
I could see a scenario where the stiffer line is better for cutting grass specifically because it's able to approach blades of grass bent towards and also away from the string. The stiff line seemed to be curled upward on one side and downward on the other -- maybe the end curved upward approaches blades bent toward the line at an angle closer to 90 degrees while the downward curved end approaches blades bent away from the line closer to 90 degrees. The stiffer line would likely hold up better against woodier brush and edging against concrete surfaces like foundations and sidewalks -- then again, it might also break easier near fence lines due to the rigidity

I used multiple versions of those oscilloscopes and carts when I worked in electronics repair, starting in the '70s and continuing well into this century. The most complex setup was used to align the heads on the Century Data 232 Hard Drives used on a flight simulator. There was an alignment disc that displayed a cats-eye pattern on the o-scope when everything was adjusted correctly. We had 6 drives, and since the disks were removable the goal was to be able to use any disk in any drive. It was a true challenge.

I get wanting to weight the grass for consistency of the tests, but in real usage they are not used in consistent conditions.  The grass is anchored at the bottom but free to move around at the top.  The wind from the line will blow the grass around. There are so many variables to consider I doubt there’s a right answer for all cases from the standpoint of giving a consistent cut. What a great video - so many good point to take in.

It seems odd to me to base your entire purchase of a line off a single test that ignores many variables. I would assume that most people want a line that makes quick work of the grass and requires less work from the user.

This testing only really proves that certain lines are better at making clean cuts, but doesn't necessarily prove anything about how well a line works in application. In my opinion, this testing is flawed as you can not apply a single variable to a complex system and understand the entire system.

I think a better testing method would be to set up a similar rig in a field of grass and observe the cutting of many grass. You would be able to see how the clumps of grass respond as a group to being hit with the line, how the air is reacting to the different shapes of line, how the weight affects going through thicker weeds, and perhaps how much force it takes to go through a test medium.

Again, it seems odd to remove all but one variable and make your decision based on that. It's sort of like saying that the sharpest knife is always the best, but then ignore what the knife is made out of or how long the blade is.

The cleanest cuts will be the result of a 2 corner string also known as a blade, but besides the fladerig of it the chance you hit the grass with the flat side is pretty high.
So putting more corners on the string makes the results more reliable and you wont have a really flat side with which you will cut uncleanly, but also you will have a thicker blade or surface at which you will hit the grass, so it will not cut as clean but also wont Shredder the grass.
so a round string is the most reliable in therms of- not hitting with a flat side, but also you have no sharp edge, since there are no corners but its round...
The circle sacrifices the sharp cut, but at lest doesn't shred every 2nd or 3rd grass by hitting with the flat side, on the other hand the square or triangle can get cleaner cuts, but can also hit with the flat side resulting in a demolition of the grass-thingy.
J would guess that the star shape is exactly in the middle of not complete flat sides and still having some sharper corners to get a good cut.
It can basically only hit with 1 or 2 corners and has no real flat side which would shreds the grass.
But this is only an estimation i found fitting for the results, hope my English isnt toooo bad and soo ;))

How tightly wound the line is on the storage roll can affect the line not hitting the same spot or flattening out into a disc. If the line had a large enough bend in it then the motion wouldn't be able to flatten it out enough. I noticed I get better results when I use line that is on a larger diameter roll where the Line isn't curved too much from being in the packaging all the time before I buy it. When I've bought line that is on a very small roll and is curved I get that same result of uneven cutting. It's a different type of weed eater head but the ones that hold straight line in chunks takes that variable away too.

I notice that the upper and lower edges have as much effect on the cut as the leading edge.  The star line does the best job of presenting an angle at the contact points of the grass blade  (leading edge, top, and bottom).   Yes, the leading edge is important, but at the speed the line is moving, having the 'edge' at the top and bottom of the line leads to more shearing because it appears to prevent the grass from bending away.

This is a good video, but I feel that a couple extra experiments would lead to a more well-rounded conclusion; a "Part 3" in the series featuring more real-world tests would greatly benefit the quality of the result, bookending the saga with a more complete picture on Weed Eater lines.
Specifically, while these tests are great for understanding how each line interacts with a single blade in isolation, they don't account for how each line handles many blades en masse. Maybe use the trolley to cut a consistent strip of grass in the garden at the same velocity with each line and compare the results?
Destin and Robert identified the potential merits of using and the Star or Sharp(Sharp) Square in different scenarios; I think it would be great to test that theory on different grass/foliage densities as well.
Furthermore, Robert's long-term experience and familiarity with Weed Eaters is an important asset and cannot be understated; it would be interesting for him to use each of the lines in his daily work, then report back his findings afterwards. While not as systematic as these synthetic tests, this real-world experience would most definitely enhance the conclusion, as there are presumably many nuanced aspects of each line, of benefit or detriment, that would be difficult or ineffective to test in isolation.
On the whole, great video, I like these sorts of practical experiments :)

@Destin My theory on why the "star line" is producing the cleanest cut is because it has multiple "cutting points" (raised edges) on the cutting surface. The initial cut is made by the furthest point forward (think 3 oclock, or parallel to the direction of travel). Then as it travels forward, it meets the second cutting point (1-2 oclock or 45 degrees from the direction of travel). This provides another defined point for impact with the grass making a shallower cut than the first one. The line continues moving forward and meets the third cutting point (12 oclock or 90 degrees from the direction of travel) allowing another even more shallow cut. This is providing 3 cuts of the grass strand per pass of the wire.
What i believe happens is that with the other cutting line shapes is that the lines are only making 1 cut per pass and are therefore imparting all their energy into one point and causing the grass strand to effectively "explode outwards" causing sheering and leaving a ragged edge.
The Star line is making multiple cuts per pass and is therefore imparting its energy into the grass strand at multiple point. Even with that the energy imparted by the line is going to be the same overall as the other lines (especially on the first cutting point), so the grass should be exploding and sheering just the same. But i think that the star lines second and third cuts at more shallow angles out pace the sheering effect that is travelling up the strand cutting it off before it can be transferred any farther and because of the shallower angles its imparting less energy to the grass so it will cut instead of sheer it.

The star shape basally is a a fanged mace. The smaller if the impact area the higher the cutting force applied. With the flanges it reduces the reliance on edge alignment by always having a flange hit the target, but increasing the odds that it hits with a flange over a flat edge, meaning it will never have the highest cutting force because it often hits with 2 flanges. Compare this to a sword, which has a since edge so is great at cutting done correctly, but if edge alignment is not perfect and hits with the flat or glances, it has little cutting force applied.

here's my deduction:
the star has 7 points, like a heptagon
imagine the top point being A, and the two points beside being B and C
when the grass hits A, it wraps around B and C, like how a whip would wrap around a pole
when that happens, the grass wants to wrap around points B and C, so there will be a same pulling force on both sides of point A, creating a pressure point
then point A rips through the grass, but since it's so thin, it works as an edge of a knife

I WAS RIGHT! I use that exact star shaped line on my big push weed eater - (yes, weed eater is the term most Okies use too), and it cut the Johnson's grass around my house the cleanest out of all the lines I've tried. If you're not familiar with Johnson's grass, it's a common feed seed that farmers grow for cattle, horses, goats, etc, and it's the devil to kill off once it gets started. It's very thick grass that grows incredibly quickly once established, can easily get 5ft tall within two weeks and is about 3/4" - 1” wide. Tough stuff. Because it's so dense, most heavier lines lay it down but the star shape goes right through it. Great video!

Test the lines on thicker clumps of grass. How fast can your cart be pushed forward through thick grass without slowing the motor too much or stalling?  That is the question we want answered.  Can you engineer a test for that with repeatable conditions and quantifiable measurements?   What we want in a weed-eater line is something that cuts thick grass or weeds the fastest.  Listen to a real weed-eater on a real lawn.  You can hear the engine rev up at the end of each pass, then bog down when it is shoved into thick grass again for the next swipe.  A skilled operator swipes as much grass as possible without stalling the engine by the end of the swipe.

Weed eater is a brand name and yes it has been co-opted as a generic word. But speaking as a small engine guy,, Weed Eater as a tool was a cheap piece of junk.  Therefore I say string trimmer or weed whacker. As to the line, dealers   choice.  I like a good quality line so it had some durability, or flail heads.  Keep in mind that the engine only has a set torque output and exceeding it causes it to bog down. So just like if the line is too long, the engine won't spin up to speed. So to if the line is too heavy.  Use the proper diameter line for your engine rating.  I like shaped line but I'm not set on a particular shape.  Whateveris on hand and the engine spins up to speed properly.

I think, perhaps;

Like pointed out, the ones with full flat sides tend to "slap" straight on.
The ones with more pointed sides have cleaner cuts due to the (roughly) same amount of force smacking on a smaller area; i.e. more pressure applied.
The star pointed one minimises the chances of a "slap", whichever direction it comes at the grass, it's likely to impact with one or two points.

-Mechanically controlled push to experiment piece
-Artiifical experiment piece (perhaps a plastic analog)
-Governed rpm on the rotary head

Hey Destin,
I think the differance between the star and the sharp sharp square has to do with the no slip boundary principle. I havent done enough research about the principle but i believe it has to do with the "viscosity" of air, and the fact that air moving near a surface is adhering to the surface slowing it down.

I feel like the star strand has smaller divits, hence making the strand less likely to have straglers that are prone to causing rips. But the sharp sharp square has much larger divits hence the blade, once cut, is likely to get caught in the divit and be trapped by the no-slip boundary principle, since the strand is not cut on both sides, the piexe stuck in the divit will pull the grass and cause it to tear.

Also the shape of the strands could make it possible for the grass cut better because, (what i see is) it is more likely for the star strand to hit the blade on a sharp part rather then the sharp sharp square (because it has more sharp parts )

I think Robert's line of thinking is right on with regards to the orange "star" line. A substantial limiting factor to the angular velocity of the line is the moment of inertia. I believe the orange "star" line has a smaller moment of inertia and therefore can achieve and maintain a higher angular velocity for the cut. The sharp sharp square is a heavier line and is probably wider; therefore acting to slow itself down via increased aerodynamic drag and larger MOI. There's probably some fancy Laminar vs. Turbulent boundary layer stuff going on as well with the star shape vs sharp sharp square shape.

I use the Milwaukee 18 volt Fuel weed eater and the same kind of string that originally came with it. Of course, they have their own brand of string too but it cuts very well and actually lasts. It's a twisted style .095 string.

I also tend to run it as slow as it will go because it still cuts (or whacks, eats, trims, whatever) grass at slower speeds and doesn't send everything flying as well as grab fences or walls as much. That probably helps with longevity too. You can hit the "rabbit" button and go full speed through thick brush too though so it's no slouch either. Yes, the tool is pricey, but you get what you pay for and I got the leaf blower "free" with the purchase of the weed eater.

I watched a Richard Hammond video the other day... He demonstrated that twisting antenna principle.

Turns out it stops cylindrical objects from extreme vibration (as they are normally susceptible to) when air passes around them.

This vibration is caused by a repeating air stream forming as air passes around the curved surface and the pressure behind the pole changes.

When a twist is added, air no longer passes uniformly around the surface of the pole but instead the air goes around the pole at different angles creating little forces in all directions.

This causes all of the little forces to cancel eachother out.

Thus, it vibrates less and creates less noise.

The twist to induce turbulence is also why you see twists going up industrial chimney stacks. They prevent the formation of Kármán vortex sheets by diverting the wind upwards on one side and downwards on the other.

How much of the "wound memory" of the line off the spool is taken into account? As you uncoil the line from the spool, the line maintains the "coil" shape of the spooling of the line. As you wind the line onto the weed eater spool that coli memory is altered, possibly not creating the single plane tracking of the two lines. I realize you're trying to control variables as much as possible, but I wonder if there's a way to test on grass that isn't being held taught. When actually running a weed whacker I don't know if I've ever cut grass that was being held firmly at both ends. The bend of the grass blade would have a huge effect on the effectiveness of trimming line. When taught the star might "cut" better than other lines that just "whack", but when just standing up the different lines might act very different.
It would also be interesting to test durability of different lines going through different plants. I would agree with the assumption that a thicker line lasts longer especially through tough brush, but who knows until it's actually tried.
I keep thinking about this and coming up with more things to try. Sometimes in the course of edging around sidewalks and stuff the line contacts dirt (if you're more highly skilled than I was at 16 you don't, but I wasn't, and everybody bites the dust sometimes). What lines stand up best to that kind of punishment? Also, what effect does the power or RPM of the weed whacker have on all this? Is an electric machine just as good or does it loose the torque needed? How fast can you swing through grass and it still be effective, or is there a ratio between power or RPM and max trimming speed? The line thins out at the end when trimming. Does a thinned out line cut better?
There are SO MANY QUESTIONS about trimming grass!

You can get some good data out of a single blade of grass, but I'm sure the results would be quite different when put through a "field test." I totally understand it's much harder to set up and there are tons of variables you can't control, but I think the conclusions you can draw from it would be better. Does the shape of the line deteriorate after moderate use, e.g. the star shape becomes more round? If you're cutting tall grass you end up cutting each blade more than once as the grass falls down onto the line. In that case, does a pulverized piece of grass (i.e. not clean cut) give less resistance later on once you get outside the context of a single blade cut?
As for those plugs that get pulled away, the star line is exactly like the sharp sharp square, but on a smaller scale. It still pulls the grass into the middle of those points, but since it's smaller, the physics work in its favor to not rip out large chunks. Short flexible stuff is more rigid than long flexible stuff. Since the groves on the sharp sharp square are wider, longer pieces of grass fit in there. Another way to think of it is to go back to the other video. Instead of the fence cutting the wire, this time the wire is cutting the grass. That same "pulley" physics are at work here with the grass wrapping around the wire. With the smaller groves, there isn't room for the grass to wrap all the way around the wire and get the same tension break you were seeing where large chunks of wire were breaking off on the fence.

Hey Destin, guess what I use weedeater line for? Knitting and sewing! I make it into a hoop that holds out the brim of knitted hats. I put some clear heat shrink tubing on about 30" of line then melt the ends with a soldering iron and push them together. Then I use the heat gun on the heat shrink over the join for good measure. Then I carefully use the heat gun to make the whole thing lie flat. Then I knit off the hem of the hat around the hoop. I figured out this refined method after I made a YouTube video about how to make the hat. I used to use the straws that come with Capri Sun. The soldering iron way is better. Anyway, what I look for is color. I like heavy gauge clear weedeater line. I also use it as a stiffener in the cases I sew for my PCB board games, like piping, but it's stiff. Great video Destin!
I'm a Development Engineer for a garden power tools company in the UK (we call it a line trimmer..), the lines that have the dimples are definitely designed to be intentionally quieter.

The noise is caused by vortex shedding, so if you have a shape that will make the air more turbulent the line will not vibrate as much, and drive a more direct path through the air. The fixed plastic 'blades' will be quieter and give a better cut still, but the downside is that if you hit a rigid object it will shatter and need to be replaced vs a line which will automatically be cut to the right length.

I think this is the reason that the star shape seems to perform best, aerodynamically it seems the best shape (like a golf ball) and so it will hit the blade of grass more consistently each time, and as you say it is faster so has more momentum when it hits the blade of grass. Also unlike the other shapes it is more uniform so whichever angle it hits the grass it is almost exactly the same, but if you take the triangular line as an example it could hit with one of the points or a flat side etc.

I may be wrong but it is interesting to see this in slow motion
